title: Empty Project.MetadataReferences for netstandard/netcoreapp Projects
body:
- I'm trying to perform code analysis on various .NET libraries
- I'm doing this with a net48 application and msbuild
- the output of Project.MetadataReferences varies according to target framework and whether some information from a separately triggered build step of the analyzed library is available

| target framework | output of MetadataReferences without previous build | output of MetadataReferences with previous build |
|--- |--- |--- |
| net48 | yes<sup>(a)</sup> | yes<sup>(a)</sup> |
| netstandard2.0 | no | yes<sup>(1)</sup><sup>(b)</sup> |
| netcoreapp2.0  | no | yes<sup>(1)</sup><sup>(c)</sup> |
| netcoreapp3.1  | no | no |

<sup>(1)</sup>: Existence of file `[lib]\obj\[lib].csproj.nuget.g.targets` from build step is sufficient. A version of this file that will __not__ work is generated during the analysis step.
<sup>(a),</sup>, <sup>(b)</sup>, <sup>(c)</sup>: see outputs at end of description

- obviously, all entries of "no" are a bit confusing to me

### Steps to reproduce

analysis app [excerpt]:
```fsharp
open System
open System.IO
open Microsoft.CodeAnalysis
open Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Text
open Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.MSBuild
open Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CSharp
open Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CSharp.Syntax
open System.Diagnostics

let msbuildWorkspace =
    MSBuildWorkspace.Create()

let openProject (workspace: MSBuildWorkspace) projectPath =
    workspace.OpenProjectAsync(projectPath).Result

let openMSBuildProject = openProject msbuildWorkspace

[<EntryPoint>]
let main argv =
    let project = argv.[0] |> openMSBuildProject
    printfn "References"
    project.MetadataReferences
```

Directory structure for one tested lib
```
tst-lib.csproj
Class1.cs
```

tst-lib.csproj (TARGET_FRAMEWORK is one of netstandard2.0, netcoreapp2.0, netcoreapp3.1, net48):
```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFramework>TARGET_FRAMEWORK</TargetFramework>
    <RootNamespace>tst_lib</RootNamespace>
  </PropertyGroup>

</Project>
```

Class1.cs:
```csharp
using System;
using System.Collections.ObjectModel;
using System.Collections.Specialized;

// some not so interesting code which is to be analysed
```

<sup>(a)</sup>: Output for net48:
```
References
"C:\Program Files (x86)\Reference Assemblies\Microsoft\Framework\.NETFramework\v4.8\mscorlib.dll"

```

nodes.body:
This sounds like the Roslyn API call doesn't restore before running its "design-time" build. I don't know if there's an explicit gesture for that in the API, or if we should consider adding it.

For now, can you run the `Restore` target on the solution before opening the MSBuildWorkspace?

Moving this to Roslyn for the questions above.
This issue was moved to dotnet/roslyn#44822

i can see the logic of opening an issue in roslyn for the other target frameworks, but if an msbuild workspace isn't returning any MetadataReferences with netcoreapp3.1, even when the project has already been built/restored, doesn't it look like there's also a potential problem in msbuild?
The concept of a "workspace" is Roslyn-specific. MSBuild doesn't have such a thing.
